Graphical abstract This review summarizes and highlights the recent progress in the research on nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER. And our perspectives on these issues and suggestions for potential areas in further work are presented. The oxygen reduction/evolution reactions (ORR/OER) are a key electrode process in the development of electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices, such as metal-air batteries and reversible fuel cells. The search for low-cost high-performance nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER alternatives to the widely-used noble metal-based catalysts is a research focus. This review aims to outline the opportunities and available options for these nanocarbon-based bifunctional electrocatalysts. Through discussion of some current scientific issues, we summarize the development and breakthroughs of these electrocatalysts. Then we provide our perspectives on these issues and suggestions for some areas in the further work. We hope that this review can improve the interest in nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER. Keywords Nanocarbon-based Oxygen reduction/evolution Bifunctional electrocatalyst Metal-free Non-precious metal 1 Introduction The fossil fuels will be exhausted in the near future, and the need for groundbreaking sustainable energy solutions has been urgent. Electrochemistry-based energy conversion and storage devices with high efficiency, reliability and environmental friendliness (such as metal-air batteries, fuel cells, water splitting, and solar fuel synthesis) have become an important component of the renewal energy systems [1–4]. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the key electrode processes for these renewal energy systems [5–8]. However, since both ORR and OER processes suffer from sluggish kinetics, the electrocatalysts catalyzing ORR/OER are critical in these fields [9–13]. At present, noble metals and their oxides, such as platinum (Pt), iridium oxide (IrO2) and ruthenium oxide (RuO2), have been demonstrated to be the best electrocatalysts for ORR or OER, but they suffer from the scarcity and high cost [14–19]. Metal-free electrocatalysts or non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) with a high ORR/OER activity and stability replacing the catalysts consist of the noble metals have become a major focus of the sustainable energy technologies research [20–28]. Due to the nanostructured carbon materials with the advantages (e.g., low cost, abundant structural variety, tailorable surface chemistry, stability within a relatively wide potential window, good conductivity and mechanical strength), the varied nanocarbon materials, such as fullerene, carbon nanoparticles/capsules/spheres, carbon nanotubes (CNTs)/fibers (CNFs), graphene, and nanoporous carbons, have been the commonly used electrocatalysts or the supporting of the electrocatalysts. However, carbon materials with the perfect structure are not catalytic active for oxygen reactions [29–32]. Therefore, recent studies of these electrocatalysts mostly focused on heteroatom doping or chemical functionalization to render nanocarbons as metal-free electrocatalysts and transition metal supported by nanocarbon or heteroatom doping/functionalization nanocarbon as NPMCs for ORR or OER [33–39]. The nanocarbon doping and functionalization with the heteroatoms (e.g., N, B, O, P, S, F) can significantly improve the catalytic activity for ORR or OER, through changing the electronic structure and chemical properties of the nanocarbon surface [40–49]. Generally, the changes derived from two factors: (1) The size and electronegativity of the heteroatom; (2) the changes in the chemical activity of the carbon atoms due to the presence of heteroatoms and doping/functionalization-induced defects [50–57]. Correspondingly, metal oxides or metal complexes in NPMCs based on transition metal (e.g., Co, Fe, Ni, Mn etc.) are catalytic active sites, while the catalysts are supported by nanocarbon to facilitate electron transfer and prevent particle agglomeration, and then presenting preferable catalytic performance for ORR or OER [58–67]. Unless otherwise stated, both metal-free catalysts and NPMCs discussed in this review are two kinds of electrocatalysts based on nanocarbons mentioned above. ORR and OER in essence are a pair of reversible reactions. In aqueous electrolytes, ORR and OER occur mainly by two pathways in acidic and alkaline electrolytes respectively, shown in the equations below: ORR Acid solution: (1) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O (3) 2H2O → O2↑ + 4H+ + 4e− OER Alkaline solution: (2) O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− (4) 4OH− → O2↑ + 2H2O + 4e− The theoretical potential needed for both ORR and OER reactions is 1.229 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) under all pH conditions, and these oxygen electrochemical reactions involve four electron transfers. Note that the practical reaction process associated with the ORR and OER on the surface of the catalysts are rather complicated, including of many intermediates and elementary steps (electron transfer or chemical reaction) depending on the natures of the catalysts and electrolytes. The ORR and OER catalytic mechanisms accepted as the best interpretation known to date are shown in Scheme 1 [68–72]. The performance of ORR and OER catalysts can be evaluated by several electrochemistry operating parameters, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The limiting current density (j), the onset overpotential (η 0) and the half-wave overpotential (η 1/2) are usually used to evaluate the catalytic activity of ORR catalysts, while the stability study is carried out by cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles in the potential range. Besides, the number of electrons transferred (n), which determine whether ORR catalyzed by the catalysts is a four-electron process, can be preliminarily obtained by the Koutecky–Levich equation shown in the equations below: (5) - 1 I = - 1 I k + 1 0.62 n F A D 2 / 3 v - 1 / 6 ω 1 / 2 C O 2 where I is the reaction current; I k is the kinetic current; n is the number of exchanged electron per O2 molecule; F is Faraday constant; A is the electrode area; D is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in the electrolyte; v is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte; C o2 the bulk concentration of O2; ω is the rotation rate of the electrode. Relatively, the method with a direct testing by a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) may be more accurate for the evaluation of the pathways. Meanwhile, the onset overpotential and the overpotential required to deliver 10 mA cm−2 of current density (ηj =10) are often used in the literature for the comparison of OER activities. 10 mA cm−2 is approximately the current density expected at the anode in a 10% efficient solar water-splitting device. The potential or overpotential required to achieve 10 mA cm−2 current density is therefore commonly used to evaluate a catalyst’s activity for OER.) And OER catalyst stability is usually evaluated by the chronopotentiometric response at a specific current density, e.g. 10 mA cm−2. In addition, comparing ORR or OER performance against the commercial noble catalysts, which are usually Pt/C for ORR and Ir/C for OER, is used as the common evaluation method for a new electrocatalyst. Meanwhile, the potential difference (ΔE) between the potential at −3 mA cm−2 (the ORR current density) and the potential at 10 mA cm−2 (the OER current density) is sometime regarded as the main evaluation factor for the overall oxygen activity of a bifunctional electrocatalysts. Noted that current densities should be normalized by the electrode geometric area; besides, the values are related with the catalyst loading on the electrode. Because more catalyst loading means more active sites under the same area of the electrode, the loading value should be focused on when the performance of the catalysts is compared. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic activity and stability of the metal-free catalysts and NPMCs for ORR or OER in acidic and alkaline solutions. Through the analysis of the data in Table 1, three important points need to be clarified: (1) The metal-free catalysts show good catalytic activity for ORR or OER only in alkaline solution. (2) Comparing metal-free catalysts, NPMCs have better catalytic activity in acid solution. (3) The stability of OER catalyst is a much greater challenge than that of ORR catalyst. Because ORR is a reduction reaction while OER is an oxidation reaction, the OER catalyst needs a higher oxidation resistance. In addition, based on Eqs. (6) and (7) below, the ‘absolute’ potential for the OER in alkaline is far lower than that in acid at the same overpotential. (6) φ RHE = φ + φ ref . + 0.0 59 × pH (7) η = φ RHE - - 1 . 229 V , where φ RHE is the potential vs. RHE, φ is the experimental potential measured with respect to the reference electrode potential (φ ref.), and η is the overpotential. The potential difference at the same overpotential between a pH = 1 solution and a pH = 14 solution is 0.8 V. Thus, an OER catalyst in acid solution will confront a most oxidizing environment; and the highest stability of the catalyst is required. Since a bifunctional catalyst for ORR and OER could be used not only for a rechargeable metal-air battery to expedite the operation of discharge and charge processes respectively, but also for a regenerative fuel cell which works as a fuel cell and in reverse as a water electrolyzer producing H2 and O2 to feed the fuel cell, the development of highly active and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts plays a key role in promoting the overall efficiency of these electrochemical devices [73–75]. Usually there are two active sites in a bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER: one for ORR and the other for OER, because the high active electrocatalysts for ORR but show poor electrocatalytic activity for OER while some electrocatalysts have extraordinary OER activity but display poor ORR activity, such as Fe/N/C as a high active catalyst for ORR shows poor activity for OER [64]; Co oxides are a high active catalyst for OER but not an active one for ORR [3]. Furthermore, the two active sites in the bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER exist in three possible forms: (1) Two active sites exist in isolation without any relation between them; (2) two active sites are coupled by the bonds; (3) two active sites are the same molecule or group. However, catalytic efficiency of the active sites in the first form is low, and the thermodynamic feasibility of one molecule or group in the third form which can catalyse both ORR and OER, a pair of reversible reactions, needs to be further discussed. In the second form, the two active sites can improve the mutual catalytic activity and stability through their interaction of coupling. At present the second form should be an ideal state of the active sites in the bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER. Aside from noble metals, a variety of the bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER have been developed such as transition metal oxides (TMO) or hydroxides [76–78], pyrochlores [79], perovskites [80–83], chalcogenides [84], nanocarbon-base materials [85–89], and metal or metal-oxide/carbon composites [90–92]. Among these bifunctional electrocatalysts, the nanocarbon-based catalysts have gained more attention because of the property and potential of nanocarbon materials applied to the electrocatalysts. As similar with the catalysts for ORR or OER, most nanocarbon-based bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER in the published works also focus on two types: metal-free catalysts and NPMCs as shown in Fig. 1(b). Then we structure this review by the different active sites under ‘metal-free’ and NPMCs. Relative to the ‘single functional’ catalysts for ORR or OER, the bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER remain as a minority, but these bifunctional catalysts have rapidly developed in the last years. We believe that a timely and comprehensive review of these bifunctional catalysts can provide the insights to accelerate the catalyst research. In this review, we focus on the recent developments of nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER. We summarize the development of these bifunctional catalysts, discuss the significant scientific issues of these catalysts (active sites and stability) and provide our perspectives on possible resolution methods. We hope that this review can generate a strong interest in these ORR/OER bifunctional catalytic materials to indicate the direction for the future strategy to search and develop low-cost catalysts for practical applications. 2 Metal-free catalysts Now the metal-free bifunctional catalysts are mainly the nanocarbon materials doped or functionalized by one or more kinds of the heteroatoms. Due to the low ORR activity and poor OER stability of the metal-free catalysts in acid media, they are only used in alkaline solution. And, noted that doping and functionalization of nanocarbon materials may introduce trace metal impurities through their presence in the synthesis reagents, which can significantly relate with the measured ORR and OER activity. And the trace metals in nanocarbons are difficult to be eliminated. Therefore, the ‘metal-free’ descriptor for theses electrocatalysts should be critical. For instance, it has been reported that Fe or Co contents as low as 0.02 wt% significantly increase the ORR activity vs. a quasi metal-free catalyst [93]. In 2015, Dai first reported that three-dimensional N and P co-doped mesoporous nanocarbon foams as the metal-free bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR/OER [57]. Consequently, some heteroatoms (such as N, P, B, S) doped/functionalized nanocarbon materials as the bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER have been studied in detail [87,94–97]. 2.1 Heteroatom mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon The study of heteroatom mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon as a bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER mainly focused on nitrogen-doped and sulfur-doped nanocarbon materials. Nitrogen atom is easy to insert inside the carbon matrix due to the very similar size between the nitrogen atom and the carbon atom. Then, in succession, N-doped nanocarbon materials were used as ORR electrocatalyst in 2009 [21] and OER electrocatalyst in 2013 [46]. It is undoubtedly logical that N-doped nanocarbon materials can be a bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER. However, it is noted that the actual ORR or OER active N-group remains elusive and is still a topic of debate. Therefore, the active sites related with ORR and OER in bifunctional catalyst are more difficult to be distinguished. Most studies toward the active sites of N-doped nanocarbon materials as bifunctional catalyst face a great difficulty. For example, the Wei group reported the use of nitrogen-doped graphene mesh as a metal-free bifunctional electrocatalysts [98]. The onset overpotential for ORR and overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for OER were 340 and 440 mV, respectively. By theoretical calculations, they also confirmed edge and topological defects as the OER active sites as shown in Fig. 2 . Only ORR stability of the catalyst was evaluated by chronoamperometry at a constant potential of 0.60 V vs. RHE. Thereafter, another bifunctional electrocatalysts of nitrogen-doped nanocarbon with sandwich-like structure (porous carbon@graphene, N-PC@G) was reported [99]. This catalyst showed a better ORR/OER activity (ORR: η 0 = 220 mV; OER: ηj =10 = 400 mV) than the previous catalysts, which maybe result from the special structure of the catalyst. The active sites of this catalyst were regrettably not mentioned and the ORR stability data of chronoamperometry at 0.62 V vs. RHE was merely included in the study. Moreover, some studies of nitrogen-doped nanocarbon catalysts have turned to the design of nanocarbon structure in order to improve the catalytic activity, such as holey graphene nanocapsule, graphene/carbon nanotube hybrids, carbon paper/graphene with core–shell architecture [100–104]. In addition, Li et al. confirmed the detail of active sites for ORR and OER by DFT computations, where active sites for the ORR were the carbon atoms at the armchair nanoribbon edge and adjacent to the graphitic N dopant while the active sites for the OER is the carbon atom near the graphitic N dopant and away from the armchair ribbon edge (in Fig. 3 ) [105]. The other heteroatom mono-doping nanocarbon, S-doped CNT, was also used as the ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts [106]. Due to a sequential two‐step strategy to dope sulphur into carbon nanotube-graphene nanolobes, the stable sulfur-carbon active‐sites were introduced and S-doped CNT showed a high catalytic activity for ORR/OER (ORR: η 0 = 350 mV; OER: ηj =10 = 360 mV). Moreover, the catalyst had a good stability under chronoamperometry at 1.67 V vs. RHE. However, the study of active sites did not be mentioned. Noted that the activity data of the catalyst of S-doped CNT were obtained in 1 M NaOH solution while the ORR/OER activity was commonly in 0.1 M NaOH. It is no doubt that the ORR/OER catalytic activity for one catalyst increases with increase of the electrolyte concentration. Then the effect of electrolyte concentration should be considered when evaluating catalytic activity. Although the heteroatom mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon, N-doped or S-doped nanocarbon materials, may be used as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER, several problems remain unresolved: (1) Two active sites for ORR and OER assigned to the atoms in these catalysts. Only one heteroatom is doped into nanocarbon while the heteroatom cannot be active sites for both ORR and OER. (2) Low catalytic activity and stability. Moreover, the heteroatom mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon has an inherent disadvantage for the bifunctional catalyst with two active sites. 2.2 Heteroatoms multi-doping/functionalization nanocarbon Compared to mono-doping/functionalization, multi-doping/functionalization nanocarbon with several heteroatoms is revealed to be more promising bifunctional electrocatalysts with high efficiency. Since the synergistic effects between co-dopants result in larger charge redistribution and more active sites, multi-doping/functionalization nanocarbon can exhibit higher catalytic activity. In addition, the distance between co-dopants is also critical to such synergistic effects and resultant activity. 2.2.1 Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon Phosphorus has a bigger atom size than carbon and a smaller electronegativity (2.19). It remains a question that the ORR/OER activity of P correlated with the model of P bonding with a peripheral C atom (edge decoration) or the in-plane graphitic C atom (lattice substitution). Although it has been proved that the ORR/OER activity of P is not higher than that of N, the higher ORR/OER activity and stability were observed when the N and P heteroatoms were simultaneously incorporated in the nanocarbon. In 2015, Dai and co-workers reported the first co-doped bifunctional catalyst in which N and P co-doped mesoporous nanocarbon was prepared as bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalyst [57]. This N, P co-doped nanocarbon material displayed a high ORR catalytic activity with onset overpotential of 290 mV, which is even equal to that of the commercial Pt/C. Meanwhile, the catalyst also exhibited a lower OER onset potential than that of RuO2 electrocatalysts (the value of ηj =10 is not mentioned in this study). Subsequently, a two-electrode rechargeable Zn-air battery with this catalyst was constructed and tested, showing cycled stability for 180 cycles at 2 mA cm−2. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate that the N, P co-doping and graphene edge effects are essential for the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity. Also, the N, P co-doped graphene/carbon nanosheets (N, P-GCNS) with sandwiching structure were fabricated [86]. The catalyst of N, P co-doped nanocarbon material exhibited an excellent catalytic activity for ORR/OER (ORR: η 0 = 220 mV; OER: ηj =10 = 340 mV). But the study of active sites and stability data were not included in this report. Additionally, a novel N, P co-doping nanocarbon material, P-doped graphitic carbon nitrides grown in-situ on carbon-fiber paper (P-g-C3N4-CFP), was used for the bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalyst [107]. This catalyst with a 3D hybrid network and high N content (13.2 wt% from XPS data) and substantial P doping, showed excellent ORR and OER activity and durability. η 0 for ORR and ηj =10 for OER were 290 and 400 mV respectively, and a strong durability was revealed by the chronoamperometric response at 0.4 and 1.63 V (in Fig. 4 ). It was believed that besides the N-induced positively charged C atoms as the active sites for both ORR and OER, P species (P+) are also critical in promoting the electroactivity. Graphitic carbon nitrides as N containing nanocarbon material with ultrahigh N content (theoretically up to 60 wt%) and stability maybe provide a platform towards metal-free bifunctional catalyst for ORR/OER. It should be mentioned that the active sites for ORR/OER in N, P co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon is not still clear. At present, it is only known that the catalyst with N, P co-doping/functionalization can exhibit better ORR/OER catalytic performance than that with N or P mono-doped/functionalization [108]. Whereas, the in-dept study toward the active sites and catalytic reason mechanism were seriously in short, such as the condition of P-N bond, the difference of the catalytic performance between P-doping/functionalization and N- functional dopants, the effect of P and N atoms interaction. 2.2.2 Nitrogen and sulfur co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon Since both N and S mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon can be used as the metal-free bifunctional catalysts, the research on N, S co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon materials have also aroused more interest. For instance, N, S co-doped mesoporous carbon nanosheets as the metal-free bifunctional catalysts have been studied for ORR/OER, which displayed a good catalytic activity (ORR: η 0 = 310 mV; OER: ηj= 10 = 420 mV) [109]. Evaluated by chronoamperometry at − 0.3, −0.5, 0.65 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) respectively, the catalyst also exhibited an excellent durability in Fig. 5 . Moreover, a self-standing bifunctional air electrode was prepared by N, S co-doped carbon (NSC) film directly growing on conductive carbon fiber paper (CFP), where NSC film and CFP were the catalyst for ORR/OER and the support respectively [110]. The advantage of the electrode may reduce the harmful effect of the binder (like nafion) as shown in Fig. 6 , which was commonly used to link the catalysts with the electrode, and enhanced the mass and charge transfer. Therefore, as-prepared electrode exhibited superior activity for both ORR (η 1/2 = 426 mV) and OER (ηj= 10 = 485 mV), as well as excellent stability in basic media with an evaluation by chronoamperometry at 0.4 and 1.63 V. Through the comparative study of the catalysts with the varied contents of N and S, it was deduced that pyridine N, graphitic N, C = S and C − S are the effective dopants for carbon lattice to catalyze ORR and OER. Additionally, several N, S co-doped nanocarbon materials have been also prepared and demonstrated as bifunctional catalyst for OER and ORR, such as N, S-enriched hierarchically porous carbon, 3D hierarchical N, S co-doped carbon nanocages, N, S co-doped carbon nanosheets and mesoporous carbon on N, S co-doped graphene nanosheets [13,111,112]. However, the study of active sites was rarely mentioned among these reports. It was only confirmed that the synergistic effect of N and S atoms was the key to the improvement of catalytic performance. Although DFT calculations indicated that structure of “graphitic N”-S-graphene related with better bifunctional catalytic activity [22,111], more questions of the active sites in N, S co-doping/functionalization catalysts have not been answered like (1) which atoms correspond with ORR activity or OER activity; (2) if N atoms bond with S atoms; (3) how is the interactor between N and S. Besides N, P and N, S co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon materials which are most studied, another heteroatoms co-doping/functionalization nanocarbon materials were also used as the metal-free bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER such as N, B co-doping/functionalization, N, O co-doping/functionalization, N, F co-doping/ functionalization, P, S co-doping/functionalization, and N, P, S tri-doping/ functionalization nanocarbon was even prepared as the bifunctional catalyst [113–120]. The studies have demonstrated these minority metal-free bifunctional catalysts can also catalyze the ORR/OER and have a reasonable stability. Consequently, it is obvious that heteroatoms both mono- and multi-doping/functionalization of nanocarbon materials can reduce metal-free electrocatalysts active for the ORR/OER in the alkaline solutions. Meanwhile, the multi-doping/functionalization bifunctional catalysts exhibit a higher catalytic activity than the mono-doping/functionalization nanocarbon materials due to the property of the bifunctional catalysts with two active sites for ORR or OER. And multi-doping/functionalization nanocarbon material will be more premising and significant research prospect for the metal-free bifunctional electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, nitrogen atom among the heteroatoms is most suitable to be doped into nanocarbon as the bifunctional catalysts due to its ORR and OER catalytic activity and stability. However, two critical issues with these carbon-based catalysts need to be pointed out: (1) Clarifying the active sites in the catalysts relating with ORR or OER; (2) their stability for the long-term use, especially under OER process. We believe that the studies of nanocarbon-based metal-free bifunctional catalysts for the ORR/OER should focus more on catalyst stability in the future. On the other hand, more studies on catalytic mechanism should be done to reveal the active sites including the synergistic effects between them and the cause for catalyst instability. 3 Non-precious metal catalysts Despite heteroatoms doping/functionalization metal-free nanocarbon materials have been proved to be an effective for bifunctional oxygen catalysis in alkaline solution, they cannot remain electrochemical stability under the oxidative OER condition. Transition metal (including alloy, oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, phosphides) supported on nanocarbon or heteroatoms doping/ functionalization nanocarbon materials have been widely explored as oxygen bifunctional NPMCs and hope to solve the poor-stability of metal-free catalysts [34,36,92,121]. 3.1 Transition metal supported by nanocarbon Although some transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, etc.) displayed a catalytic activity for ORR/OER, the metals can hardly be used directly due to their poor conductivity, especially the metal oxide with higher catalytic activity [122–127]. Then an approach is based on composites obtained by combining transition metal with electroconductive supports, where nanocarbon seems to be the best choice. The hybrid form of transition metal supported by nanocarbon can obtain the advantages of the inherent properties of each component such as electrochemical reactivity, mechanical stability, and electrical/ionic conductivity [128]. Moreover, nanocarbon material cannot only improve the conductivity of the catalyst, but also prevent the aggregation of the nanosized particles and increase the dispersion of metal particles as active sites to obtain better catalytic activity. The property was achieved by simply mixing the transition metal oxides with carbons. Thus, transition metal supported by nanocarbon was used as effective bifunctional NPMCs for ORR/OER. Currently, Co-based electrocatalysts were most studied as attractive ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts in alkaline electrolytes due to their high electrocatalytic activity and environmental friendliness. To date, several types of Co-based/nanocarbon were mainly used as bifunctional catalysts, including oxides (Co x O/NPs), binary oxides (Co3O4/ZTC) and spinel oxides with the formula of AB2O4 (CoFe2O4/CNTs, FeCo2O4/HrGOS, CoMn2O4-NF/C, CoFe2O4 nanoparticles/RC, etc.) [129–140]. For example, the cobalt oxide nanoparticle with size-dependent (3–10 nm) structure deposited on carbon nanotubes (CoO x /CNTs) as the bifunctional catalysts was studied for ORR/OER [141]. CoO x /CNTs catalyst exhibited an efficient catalytic activity for ORR/OER, where η 1/2 for ORR and ηj =10 for OER were 530 and 390 mV, respectively. And a good durability of CoO x /CNTs was evaluated by chronopotentiometry at 5 mA cm−2. More importantly, in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to explore the structural changes and reaction pathways of cobalt oxide as active sites for ORR/OER. It was demonstrated that Co3O4 and CoOOH as the major species were not related with the CoO x particle size under both OER and ORR conditions, as shown in Fig. 7 . The OER activities of the CoO x /CNTs increased with decreasing particle size, which resulted from the increased oxidation state and larger surface area of the smaller nanoparticles. The ORR activity was independent of the CoO x nanoparticle size, revealing the auxiliary role of CoO x on the CoO x /CNTs for the reduction or disproportionation of peroxide rather than the reduction of oxygen. The dominant Co (III) species which were related to active intermediates for the OER, appeared to be side products generated from the oxidation of Co (II) by a peroxide intermediate during the ORR. Besides, Ni, Fe, Mn-based, single-metal or bimetals supported on nanocarbon materials were also reported as bifunctional NPMCs [142–144]. For instance, a bifunctional NPMCs for ORR/OER with a 3D porous graphene aerogel-supporting Ni combined with MnO species (Ni-MnO/rGO) was developed [142]. The resulting Ni-MnO/rGO aerogels displayed the bifunctional catalytic performance for both ORR and OER in an alkaline electrolyte (ORR: η 0 = 350 mV; OER: ηj= 10 = 318 mV; stability evaluation by chronopotentiometry at 10 mA cm−2), which can compete with the reported bifunctional electrocatalysts at that time. It was revealed that the MnO mainly contributes to the high activity for the ORR, while metallic Ni is responsible for the excellent OER activity. Although these transition metal supported by nanocarbon catalysts delivered a relatively good catalytic performance for ORR/OER, the nanocarbon material played a simple role, which were conducting materials and avoided the aggregation of the metal nanoparticles. Because the nanocarbon did not commonly bond with the transition metal, the electrical/ionic conductivity and synergistic effect between both atoms were still limited. Even, the loss of nanoparticles may be caused during the catalysis process, and thus degrade their electrocatalytic durability and performance. To further improve the catalytic performance of the transition metal-base catalyst, the metal atom should be better connected with the nanocarbon. Furthermore, numerous advantages of the nanocarbon support should be exploited beyond its role as a nanomaterial carrier, which potentially include defect-induced modification and synergistic effects for enhanced electrocatalytic performance. 3.2 Transition metal supported by heteroatom doping/functionalization nanocarbon In order to further enhance electrocatalytic activities of NPMCs, heteroatoms doping/functionalization of nanocarbon materials incorporated with transition metals or metal oxides are the most popular method to create efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts, where the heteroatoms are just a “bridge” between metal and nanocarbon. It can be resulted in better electrical/ionic conductivity of both atoms to derive a better catalytic activity and stability of the bifunction catalysts. In the other hand, the heteroatom themselves are the active sites for ORR/OER. This causes these NPMCs containing heteroatoms with better catalytic performance than the catalysts without heteroatoms mentioned above. 3.2.1 Co-based supported by heteroatom doping/functionalization nanocarbon 3.2.1.1 Co-based oxide Recently, Co-based materials including cobalt oxide, cobalt sulfide, Co-N-Cand Co-based single atoms, supported by heteroatoms (such as N, B, P) doping/functionalization nanocarbon as effective bifunctional NPMCs for ORR/OER in alkaline solution, have attracted the most extensive attention [24,65,92,145]. The Wu group reported cobalt oxide supported by heteroatoms doping/functionalization nanocarbon as the bifunctional NPMCs, which comprises CoO x nanoparticles rich in oxygen vacancies grown on B, N-decorated graphene (CoO x NPs/BNG) [146]. The hybrid electrocatalyst exhibited a highly efficient catalytic activity for ORR/OER, where η 0 for ORR and ηj= 10 for OER were 280 and 295 mV, respectively. Meanwhile, it was demonstrated by X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) that abundant Co-N-C acted as strong bridging bonds between CoO x NPs and B, N-decorated graphene sheets in Fig. 8 . Co-N-C species offered numerous active sites, enhanced electron transfer ability, and a strongly synergetic coupled effect, which also indicated the advantage of the heteroatoms as the bridge between metal and carbon. In the meantime, other hybrid bifunctional catalysts with varied Co-based oxides were also reported, such as Co3O4/N-csCNT, Co@Co3O4/NC, Co/N-CNSNs, Co-CoO/N- studies of Co-based oxides bifunctional catalysts, Co3O4 as cobalt nanoparticle was most used due to its relatively high catalytic activity, low economic cost and excellent stability of Co3O4 spinel structure. Moreover, heteroatoms-doped carbon matrix can enhance the catalytic performance of the Co3O4 because of the strong synergistic interaction between Co3O4 and heteroatoms-doped carbon. More importantly, the rGO and bimetal catalysts (Co3O4/Fe@C2N, CuCo2O4@N-C) [147–175]. Among these strong synergistic interaction was commonly considered as active sites for ORR/OER, although the conclusions only resulted from DFT computation or deduction. In addition, some catalysts with the special structure and morphology were rationally designed and elaborately tuned to achieve the expected catalytic performance. For instance, core–shell spinel Co oxide nanoparticles (Co@Co3O4, metallic Co core with Co3O4 shell) encapsulated in in-situ formed N-doped carbon nanotube-grafted carbon polyhedra by reductive carbonization of N-containing metal–organic frameworks (MOF), was synthetized and subsequent controlled oxidative calcination as shown in Fig. 9 [151]. The as-synthesized catalyst showed excellent performance as bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER under alkaline conditions. The half-wave overpotential (η 1/2) for ORR and overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for OER were 430 and 420 mV, respectively. Chronoamperometric (for ORR at 0.77 V) and chronopotentiometric (for OER at 10 mA cm−2) measurements showed no significant loss in activity after 25 and 45 h, respectively, indicating that the bifunctional catalyst with the core–shell structure was able to sustain a stable performance over a long period of time. In addition, the carbonization of MOFs has been a widely used approach to obtain bifunctional NPMCs, which did not only have highly nanoporous carbons with the simultaneous incorporation of intrinsic ligand heteroatoms and metal centres within the carbon matrix, but also owned the different structure from rationally designed MOFs [176–180]. Co-based oxide supported by heteroatom doping/functionalization nanocarbon as most common electrocatalysts for OER and ORR generally displayed a good catalytic performance in the alkaline solution. Noted that intrinsic electrical conductivity and well-dispersant of these materials need to be focused on in the future study. 3.2.1.2 Co-based sulfide The large efforts have been also made to develop Co-based sulfides as ORR/OER bifunctional cost-effective electrocatalysts. It was found that Co-based sulfides possess the high activity for oxygen reactions, which was predicted by theoretic calculations to possess good kinetics close to the noble metal [181]. On the basis of these predictions, recently several Co-based sulfides materials were synthesized, including CoS2, CoS x and Co9S8 for ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts [73,182–190]. Shanmugam et al. reported a novel and facile synthesis of CoS2 nanoparticles grown in situ on N, S-doped graphene oxide, CoS2/N, S-GO [73]. The as-prepared catalyst exhibited good bifunctional activity of η 0 = 260 mV for ORR and ηj= 10 = 380 mV for OER. And it was deduced that this excellent performance was due to the spherical development of CoS2 on the graphene and anchoring of CoS2 on the graphene. Nevertheless, another CoS2-based bifunctional catalyst with special structure of “ship in a bottle” was reported [189]. CoS2 was immobilized inside the S-doped defective carbon pores (CoS2/SKJ). Each individual pore acted as a nanoreactor, interconnecting with each other for efficient oxygen electrocatalysis, as illustrated in Fig. 10 . The as-developed CoS2/SKJ catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity for ORR/OER (ORR: η 0 = 310 mV; OER: ηj =10 = 350 mV). Meanwhile, the structure of “ship in a bottle” played a more significant role in the catalyst stability, where CoS2/SKJ showed an ORR/OER good stability evaluated via a chronoamperometry at 0.7 V, 1.6 V and CV (3500 cycles) measurements. Additionally, it has been revealed that this designed catalyst with superior electrochemicalperformance should be associated with the synergistic effect between defect-rich interfaces and effective catalytic active sites (CoS2 and C−S−C bonding) guarantees. In 2016, an advanced bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR/OER was first designed, the graphene supported Co9S8 nanoparticles (Co9S8/G) by simultaneously etching and doping a cobalt sulfides-graphene hybrid with NH3-plasma [186]. N-doped Co9S8/G shows excellent ORR activity, η 0 = 289 mV, and great OER activity, ηj =10 = 400 mV. Also, the study clarified that two issues contributed significantly to the enhanced electrocatalytic performance for ORR/OER: (1) The heteroatom doping efficiently tuning the electronic properties of Co9S8 and graphene; (2) exposing more active sites for electrocatalysis by the surface etching. In addition, an investigation on the catalyst with Co9S8 nanoparticles also confirmed that cobalt with low valence, Co2+, may be active sites for ORR and OER by the comparative study [187]. Similar with Co-based oxide, Co-based sulfide materials were also the good bifunctional catalysts for ORR and OER. However, the active sites of these Co-based sulfide materials were not clear due to lack of the depth study. In addition, both the electrical conductivities and the utilization efficiency of the active sites should be further improved. 3.2.1.3 Co-based single-atom catalysts Single-atom catalysts (SACs), with the metal atoms distributed on the support surface, have recently become a new frontier in catalysis and have attracted more research interest. Many traditional NPMCs lead to a high metal consumption due to a low metal utilization efficiency, while SACs always have the maximum atom-utilization efficiency. Notably it is a key point for SACs that a suitable support is selected to efficiently anchor the isolated metal atoms and further prevent the aggregation of these atoms. Thus, Co-based single-atom materials have been used as bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER [191–196]. Among the Co-based catalysts, Co-SACs obtain some significant advantages, such as a high atom utilization, high active site exposure, low-coordination, and unique catalytic performance. Meanwhile, strong electronic and covalent interactions between Co single atoms and the supporting matrix greatly improve the stability of the catalysts. The Pennycook group reported a Co SA electrocatalyst assembled in nitrogen-doped porous carbon nanoflake arrays (NC-Co SA), which was fabricated by a facile carbonization-acidification process using metal organic frameworks as the precursor material [191]. The NC-Co SA shows excellent ORR/OER performance, ORR η 0 = 230 mV; OER: ηj =10 = 360 mV. And it was demonstrated that the Co single atoms were bonded to N atoms, subsequently well dispersed and stably attached to the surface of the N-doped carbon flakes, which Co-N x was also considered as active sites for ORR/OER in NC-Co SA electrocatalyst. Another Co-based single-atom material with higher site fraction of Co atoms (≈15.3%) was used as ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts, where a salt-template method for scalable synthesis of high-density, monodispersed Co single atoms on a N-doped 2D carbon nanosheet (SCoNC), simply by pyrolysis of KCl particles wrapped with Co-based organic framework (ZIF-67), as shown in Fig. 11 [192]. For the ORR/OER test, the SCoNC catalyst exhibited 320 mV η 1/2 (ORR) and 310 mV ηj =10 (OER) respectively. In this study, DFT calculations suggested that the Co-N4 sites on the carbon matrix are the most active sites for bifunctional ORR and OER activity. In addition, it need be mentioned that a Co-based single-atom catalyst with Co−N−C complex as active sites displayed the state-of-the-art ORR catalytic activity among ORR/OER bifunctional NPMCs (η 0: 180 mV), while the OER activity did not reach a high level (ηj =10: 470 mV) [196]. Co-based single-atom catalysts as the higher efficiency bifunctional catalysts really were the most promising catalyst for ORR and OER. At present, “Single-atom” should be just Co complexes, such as Co-N4. The study, which “Single-atom” metal Co or Co oxides with the higher catalytic performance was used as the bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER, will be a focus in the future. 3.2.1.4 Co-based phosphides and hydroxides Combining Co-based phosphides and hydroxides with nanocarbon-based materials were also an efficient strategy to obtain the high performance OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts [197–200]. However, comparing with the catalysts of cobalt oxide and cobalt sulfide, the studies of two types catalysts were the minority. For example, the OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts, synthesized by nanoscale amorphous cobalt hydroxide (Co(OH) x ) anchoring N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs), does not only exhibits an excellent OER activity (ηj= 10 = 350 mV) and moderate ORR activity (η 0 = 360 mV), but also a superior cycling stability in an alkaline condition [197]. It was also revealed that N-dopants facilitated electron tunnelling to the oxygen reactant to lower work function of CNTs and well contributed a 4e reduction pathway during ORR, whereas the abundant charge carriers in amorphous Co(OH) x species mainly conducted the superior OER activity with high current density and low Tafel slope. Since few researches on Co-based phosphides and hydroxides were reported, the active sites and the mechanism need to be deeply studied in the future. Compared with other Co-based catalysts, the stability of these Co-based phosphides and hydroxides material should also be more focused on. 3.2.2 Other transition metal-based supported by heteroatom doping/functionalization nanocarbon Similarly, Fe, Ni, Mn and other transition metals-based supported by heteroatom doping/ functionalization nanocarbon were also used as bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER [90,201–211]. For instance, a Fe-based bifunctional electrocatalyst, Fe, N co-doped porous graphene-like carbon hybrids with Fe3C encapsulated in graphitic layers (Fe3C@NG), was synthesized by a facile approach of a one-step solid-state thermal reaction [90]. The as-prepared catalyst exhibited excellent bifunctional catalytic activity toward both ORR and OER, along with high catalytic efficiency and long-term stability (ORR: η 0 = 240 mV; OER: ηj= 10 = 361 mV; durability evaluated by chronoamperometry at 1.59 V and 3000 CV cycles). Additionally, the study indicated that ORR performance of this catalyst was attributed to a large specific surface area, high percentage of pyridinic-N and graphitic-N dopants, a trace amount of Fe-N x species, and the existence of an Fe3C phase, while Fe-related species (Fe3C and Fe-N x ) may be active sites for OER. Ni-based materials as ORR/OER bifunctional NPMCs were also studied. For instance, multifunctional electrocatalyst consisting of dominant metallic Ni with small fraction of oxides anchored onto nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (Ni-NiO/N-rGO) was prepared via a pyrolysis of graphene oxide and nickel salts [162]. Although Ni-NiO/N-rGO exhibited a high electrocatalytic activity for OER with ηj= 10 = 0.24 V, unfortunately the catalytic activity for ORR was poor. Then the bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER only containing Ni species should be further studied due to their poor catalytic activity for ORR. Nevertheless, a catalyst with FeNi alloy and nitrogen-codoped porous carbon (FeNi-NC) exhibited not only satisfactory ORR electrocatalytic activities (η 0 = 250 mV), but also excellent OER performance (ηj= 10 = 380 mV). During the testing of rechargeable Zn-air battery, the FeNi-NC catalyst also showed long-term cycle stability [202]. It leads a way to synthesize the bifunctional NPMCs for ORR/OER with both Fe and Ni species, where Fe and Ni species are the active sites for ORR and OER respectively due to Fe species with better ORR catalytic activity and Ni with higher activity for OER. It is obvious that heteroatom doping/functionalization of nanocarbon materials instead of nanocarbon as the supporting for transition metal can enhance the electrocatalysts active and stability for ORR/OER in alkaline solutions due to the “bridge” function of these heteroatoms. However, the stability for long-term use is still the critical issue for these bifunctional NPMCs, particularly the durability during OER process. Therefore, comparing with initial activity, more research on the stability of these bifunctional NPMCs for ORR/OER will be needed in the future. In addition, the future studies should also focus on the structure of active sites and structure-performance relationship in order to unravel catalytic mechanism. Table 2 summarizes some selected metal-free catalysts and NPMCs nanocarbon-based bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER reported. 4 Conclusions and perspective This review highlights the recent progress in the research on nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER. Through an objective comparison of important parameters for the catalysts performance, it can be confirmed that both nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal materials are the promising bifunctional catalysts for ORR/OER substitute for the noble metal catalysts in alkaline solution. Although a significant progress on the catalytic activity of these bifunctional catalysts has been made, some key scientific challenges remain to be the hinder of the catalyst design with the higher performance. The active sites for ORR/OER and the catalysis mechanisms on these bifunctional catalysts are not well revealed. Although some in-situ techniques such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy could provide valuable information about the local structure, the reconstruction of catalyst surface during the catalytic process is still difficult to be characterized, especially for the complicated multiphase catalysts. Due to the bifunctional properties, the catalysts need to contain two active centres for ORR and OER respectively, which will be ever-increasing difficulty to confirm the active sites and reveal the structure of active sites. In addition, density functional theory calculations are increasingly used in the catalyst studies to obtain the insights into the catalysis mechanism (reaction pathways and postulate the reaction rate-limiting step in electrocatalysis) and the prediction of the active sites. But there is a large gap for completely clarifying the active sites and some important mechanisms because the calculations are usually “surface static”, while the complexity of bifunctional catalyst surface cannot be constructed in the model of the calculation. Based on the summary of the review, the determination of active sites in the bifunctional catalysts reported mostly results from the calculations and the deduction, where synergistic effect between two heteroatoms or heteroatom and transition metal are roughly considered as the active sites for ORR/OER. However, the fundamental problems toward active sites and stability of these bifunctional catalysts, which are not still cleat at present, such as the active sites in the catalysts relating with oxygen reduction or oxygen evolution respectively, the structure of the active sites, and the relationship between their interaction and catalytic performance. Due to the lack of the in-depth research on the active sites, the further growing of high-performance bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER is seriously limited. Therefore, the development of new approaches suitable for unravelling the active sites and the mechanism is needed, as well as more in situ techniques which can characterize the catalyst surface under the reaction conditions. The stability of ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts is a critical issue, especially during the OER process. Due to the higher oxidation potential (>1.23 V vs. RHE) under the OER process, the stability of the catalysts in the OER process should attract a more attention than that in the ORR process. Then, comparing with the transition metal, the stability of heteroatoms doping/functionalization nanocarbon materials should be more focused on. However, some studies of the bifunctional catalysts only evaluated the stability during the ORR process without testing in the OER. In addition, both the active sites corrosion and catalyst support corrosion should be noted. It is still a great challenge to enhance the durability of the bifunctional catalysts. One possible solution is to use corrosion-protection techniques to improve the stability of the catalysts. For example, a recent study reported the electrochemical degradation of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) under the acidic OER environment [212]. Since structural changes of MWCNTs were caused by electrochemical oxidation, the more oxygen-containing groups could be formed on the carbon surface, which inhibited further degradation of the graphitic underlayers in the MWCNTs, thereby improved the stability of carbon-based catalysts and provided the possibility of using these nanocarbon materials for OER in acid. Meanwhile, more study is also needed to improve the native stability of these bifunctional catalysts. Besides, the criteria of evaluated stability should be uniform, where the ORR test should be over 1000 CV cycles and the OER measurement should be done by chronoamperometry at ηj= 10 or chronopotentiometry at 10 mA cm−2. At present, most of nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER was only used in alkaline solution, while these materials as bifunctional catalysts in neutral and acid media, are rarely reported. However, the corrosion and CO2 carbonation problems are not only avoided under neutral condition, but also the operation is more safety. And OER in acid solution also has the advantage of a higher voltage efficiency and higher energy density than that in alkaline. But, the continuing search for nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER for neutral or acid solution is still a great challenge, because these bifunctional catalysts with a good performance in alkaline media usually show either a low catalytic activity or poor stability under neutral and acid condition. The best approach to develop high performance nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER should firstly base on revealing the active sites for ORR/OER and the understandings from the catalytic mechanism. Meanwhile, to optimize the electrocatalytic activity of these catalysts, the following strategies are typically adopted: (1) The design of different nanostructures (nanocarbon or both nanocarbon and transition metal particle) to increase the number and the accessibility of the active sites; (2) combining different ORR/OER active materials by strongly coupled interfaces and improving the catalytic performance by maximizing the synergistic effects; (3) enhancing the mass-transfer efficiency by introducing mesoporous materials and 3D architectures. Moreover, using nanocarbon-based catalysts with the advantage of a good conductivity, a large nanocarbon surface area for exposing more active sites, and the hydrophilization of the hydrophobic carbon surface are also the significant measures of enhancing catalytic activity. And based on the property which nanocarbon materials can be stable at high potential and in acid media, the design of perfect nanocarbon structure to protect the active sites is an improving stability method. In view of the summary of nanocarbon-based bifunctional catalysts, nitrogen and cobalt can be considered as the most promising active sites for the metal-free and NPMCs respectively. Meanwhile, multi-doping (such as N, P co-doped; N, S co-doped) and two metal atoms mixing (such as Fe, Ni alloy) should have more advantage for two active sites for ORR and OER in the bifunctional catalysts. Also, maximizing the atom-utilization efficiency by designing single-atom will be a focus in the future study of the bifunctional catalysts. Yansong Zhu received his Ph.D. degree at Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2015, and then went to National University of Singapore (Singapore) as a research staff in the Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering from 2016 to 2018. Now he is an associate professor in Faculty of Pharmacy, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. His study focuses on the development of high-performance and durable carbon-based metal-free/non-precious metal electrocatalysts for ORR and OER. Bingsen Zhang obtained his Ph.D. degree at Northeastern University (China) in 2009, and then went to Fritz Haber Institute of Max Planck Society in Berlin (Germany) as a postdoctoral fellow in the Department of Inorganic Chemistry. In 2011, he joined Institute of Metal Research (IMR), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and received an IMR SYNL-T.S. Kê Research Fellowship founded by Shenyang National Laboratory for Materials Science (SYNL). Now he is a professor of IMR CAS. His main research interest is the microstructure investigation of nanocatalysts and energy conversion and storage materials.

coredata.dc:description: The oxygen reduction/evolution reactions (ORR/OER) are a key electrode process in the development of electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices, such as metal-air batteries and reversible fuel cells. The search for low-cost high-performance nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER alternatives to the widely-used noble metal-based catalysts is a research focus. This review aims to outline the opportunities and available options for these nanocarbon-based bifunctional electrocatalysts. Through discussion of some current scientific issues, we summarize the development and breakthroughs of these electrocatalysts. Then we provide our perspectives on these issues and suggestions for some areas in the further work. We hope that this review can improve the interest in nanocarbon-based metal-free and non-precious metal bifunctional electrocatalysts for ORR/OER.
